channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: 2 Paths for Yemen’s War-Scarred Children: Combat, or Marriage
item.media:description: A camp of displaced Yemenis in the western village of Khamer. In a humanitarian crisis caused by the war, children are bearing much of the burden.
item.description: The country is facing a humanitarian crisis that is threatening the lives, health and futures of its young people.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Execution Still Haunts Village, 50 Years After Che Guevara’s Death
item.media:description: A statue of Che Guevara in La Higuera, the Bolivian town where he was killed in 1967.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Residents of a tiny Bolivian hamlet vividly recall the day the guerrilla leader was shot at their school. “For us, this was a time of suffering,” says a woman who brought him soup.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Jerusalem Journal: In Jerusalem, Looking for Peace in Backgammon and Music
item.media:description: The Palestinian rapper Muhammad Mughrabi and the Israeli poet Adi Keissar on stage during the Mekudeshet festival in Jerusalem.
item.description: After years of impasse in the peace process, a growing number of Israelis and Palestinians are seeking new ways of crossing the dividing lines
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Kim Jong-un of North Korea, in Rare Show of Confidence, Promotes His Sister
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, left, and his sister Kim Yo-jong in Pyongyang in April. Ms. Kim is often seen accompanying her brother at state functions and on tours of military units and factories.
item.description: The sister, Kim Yo-jong, who is the only one of Mr. Kim’s siblings active in his government, was made an alternate member of the Politburo.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Red Cross Reduces Presence in Afghanistan After Staff Is Attacked
item.media:description: A Red Cross hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, last year. The organization has provided more than 19,000 artificial limbs and other devices in the country every year through seven rehabilitation centers.
item.description: Following a series of killings and abductions, the organization said it would withdraw from two northern provinces and close an urban hub.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and NAJIM RAHIM
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Germany’s Angela Merkel Agrees to Limits on Accepting Refugees
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin on Monday with Horst Seehofer, leader of the Christian Social Union party in Bavaria, who has been demanding for months that a limit be set on the number of people allowed to apply for asylum in Germany.
item.description: Keeping asylum arrivals to 200,000 a year is a condition for a conservative party, Bavaria’s Christian Social Union, to join her new coalition.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Cash, T-Shirts and Gallons of Booze: How Liberian Candidates Woo Voters
item.media:description: Pen-pen motorcycle drivers wearing Alternative National Congress T-shirts wait for passengers outside a rally in Monrovia, Liberia, on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: As a national election looms, Liberians game the system, squeezing largess out of political candidates.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: U.S. and Turkey Try to Prevent a Diplomatic Dispute From Growing
item.media:description: The United States Consulate in Istanbul on Monday. A Turkish employee of the consulate was arrested last week on charges related to a failed coup last year.
item.description: After the arrest of a Turkish employee of an American consulate, both sides suspended visa services before taking some steps to ease tensions that have been brewing for months.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Women Today: Women Are Playing Today, and Leading Tomorrow
item.media:description: A player for the women’s soccer team from Kabul, Afghanistan, left, vied for the ball against a team from Herat in 2014 during the country’s first women’s league final at the Afghanistan Football Federation’s stadium in Kabul.
item.description: Sports programs for girls provide more than just a physical benefit — they can also help educate girls about gender issues, and empower them.
item.dc:creator: JULIET MACUR

item.title: Women Today: Successful Career Women Finish the Phrase ‘If Only …’
item.media:description: Hindou Oumarou Ibrahim spoke at the United Nations in April 2016 before the signing of the Paris climate accord. She is the coordinator of Afpat, a community-based organization to protect the rights of the indigenous people of Chad.
item.description: Women attending the Women’s Forum for the Economy and Society in Paris reflected on how they might have altered their own paths and how to empower more women.
item.dc:creator: ALINA TUGEND

item.title: Women Today: Careers for Women in Technology Companies Are a Global Challenge
item.description: While companies in the United States are the ones that make headlines because of gender issues, women say the problems exist elsewhere as well.
item.dc:creator: ALINA TUGEND

item.title: Feature: The Prophet of Germany’s New Right
item.media:credit: Gene Glover for The New York Times
item.description: From a tiny village in the country’s rural east, a leading nationalist intellectual builds a vision for the future of his movement across Europe.
item.dc:creator: JAMES ANGELOS

item.title: Women Today: Readers Speak Out on Goals and Challenges of Women Today
item.description: We asked readers what were the challenges facing women in the work force and what did they think needed to be done to support their needs? Here are some of the responses.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Europe Edition: Catalonia, Donald Trump, World Cup: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: A Jail Stay Kept Secret for an Accused Terrorist
item.description: Court papers raised questions about how jail officials handled someone the government viewed as an important defendant.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Hervé Leroux, Creator of the Hervé Léger Bandage Dress, Dies at 60
item.media:description: Hervé L. Leroux, then known as Hervé Léger, during a fashion show in Paris in 1995.
item.description: At the height of his fame Mr. Leroux dressed celebrities and jet-setters in his figure-hugging creations. Then he lost control of the name that had made him famous.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH PATON

item.title: Retro Report: Trump’s Argument Against Immigrants: We’ve Heard It Before
item.description: President Trump wants to sharply limit immigrants and refugees. His efforts, and the resulting backlash, echo the debate over a 1994 California referendum.
item.dc:creator: CLYDE HABERMAN

item.title: Clean Power Plan, Harvey Weinstein, N.F.L.: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: For Belfast, ‘America First’ Amounts to ‘Northern Ireland Last’
item.media:description: A Bombardier factory in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The Trump administration, under pressure from Boeing, has proposed a tariff of nearly 300 percent on imports of Bombardier’s newest plane.
item.description: A Trump administration decision to impose a nearly 300 percent tariff on imports of a new plane threatens thousands of jobs and the peace process.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: China Hastens the World Toward an Electric-Car Future
item.media:description: A driver waiting for his electric car to be charged at a station in Beijing. Already the world’s largest maker and buyer of electric cars, China is forcing the rest of the auto industry toward a battery-powered future.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: The biggest automakers in the world are being forced to follow Beijing’s lead as China takes steps to dominate in electric vehicles and technology.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Catalonia Independence Fight Produces Some Odd Bedfellows
item.media:description: People in Barcelona leaving a rally promoting unity with Spain held Sunday in response to the disputed referendum on Catalan independence.
item.description: The anarchists, free marketeers and social democrats united in a quest for sovereignty agree on little else, which could become a problem.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY and RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Liberia’s Women Warn Male Presidential Candidates: Keep the Peace
item.media:description: Women’s groups marching in Monrovia on Monday, the day before Liberians head to the polls to elect a new president.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: A man will almost certainly become the country’s next leader, and women are worried that their newfound gains will be lost.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Kim Jong-un, Catalonia, Turkey: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Europe Edition: Catalonia, Turkey, Harvey Weinstein: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Che Guevara’s Fiery Life and Bloody Death
item.media:description: The body of Che Guevara, the hero of Latin American revolutionaries, on display in Bolivia in 1967. Guevara was buried secretly and found 30 years later, when his remains were brought to Cuba.
item.description: Fifty years after the revolutionary leader was shot to death in Bolivia, his symbolic power remains.
item.dc:creator: ZACH JOHNK

item.title: U.S. Suspends Visa Services in Turkey, and Turkey Responds in Kind
item.description: Both government announced the suspension of nonimmigrant visa services on Twitter. The United States said the action was “effective immediately.”
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russians in Silicon Valley Can’t Shake Hacking’s Shadow
item.media:description: Pavel Cherkashin, a Russian investor, is turning a church in San Francisco into a tech space, which he planned to call Hack Temple. He is having second thoughts about the name.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: While headlines about election interference have bolstered their tech reputation, many find themselves the target of jokes and even suspicion.
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Ugandan Rebel Group Massacres 22 in Congo
item.description: The killings were carried out by members of the Allied Democratic Forces, an Islamist militant group accused of killing hundreds of people in recent years.
item.dc:creator: STEVE WEMBI

item.title: Chinese Village Where Xi Jinping Fled Is Now a Monument to His Power
item.media:description: Liangjiahe, where President Xi Jinping of China spent a formative period of his youth during the Cultural Revolution, has been converted into a tourist attraction that attempts to show how the village helped forge his strongman style.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: On the cusp of China’s leadership shake-up, a village where President Xi Jinping spent seven years as a youth now draws pilgrims and a propaganda drive.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: In Nigeria and Cameroon, Secessionist Movements Gain Momentum
item.media:description: Supporters of the Indigenous People of Biafra, a separatist group, in southeast Nigeria in May. Nigeria’s president, Muhammadu Buhari, declared the group a terrorist organization last month.
item.description: Calls for independence from regions in both countries are growing in the wake of violent crackdowns from security forces that have killed supporters.
item.dc:creator: TONY IYARE and FRANCOIS ESSOMBA

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: North Korea, Catalonia, Hurricane Nate: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: ‘I Am Spanish’: Thousands in Barcelona Protest a Push for Independence
item.media:description: Thousands rallied in Barcelona, Spain, on Sunday in support of a united Spanish state and against agitators for independence.
item.description: Demonstrators who oppose separation from Spain expressed solidarity with the vilified national police and waved the national flag.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: North Korean Leader Hails Nuclear Arsenal as ‘Powerful Deterrent’
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, center, the North Korean leader, and other officials at a meeting of the ruling Workers’ Party on Saturday in Pyongyang.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Kim Jong-un struck a defiant tone after President Trump said diplomacy had failed to end the crisis. And South Korean officials were worried that the North would conduct a major test Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: In Trailblazing Tokyo Governor, Japan Meets Its Great Disrupter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, second from right, and Yuriko Koike, center, the governor of Tokyo, were among the leaders who participated in a debate in Tokyo on Saturday.
item.description: Yuriko Koike and her new party could derail Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s bid for a record-setting tenure in office, though she isn’t yet running herself.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: ISIS Fighters, Having Pledged to Fight or Die, Surrender en Masse
item.media:description: The suspected Islamic State fighters received food at a security screening center near Kirkuk.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: More than 1,000 militants turned themselves in after the latest in a string of humiliating defeats in Iraq and Syria. Many claim to have been only cooks or clerks.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Suspected ISIS Members Surrender in Iraq
item.description: In the days since Iraqi forces declared victory over Islamic State fighters in Hawija, the group’s final urban stronghold in the country, more than 1,000 men have turned themselves in to the Kurdish authorities.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Vic Journal: Catalonia’s Push for Independence Has an Unlikely Symbol: Tractors
item.media:description: In the fertile valley near Vic, Spain, farmers are working their fields but also playing a leading role in the demonstrations for independence in Catalonia.
item.description: Farmers have long played a defining role in Catalonian identity. Now they are playing a big role in the independence movement, by using their tractors.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Gas Station Explosion in Ghana Kills at Least 7 and Injures Over 100
item.media:description: Fire investigators at the site of burned cars and trucks on Sunday after the gas tanker explosion in Accra, Ghana.
item.description: The explosion in Accra, Ghana’s capital, which injured at least 132 others, sent up giant balls of fire that lit up the night sky.
item.dc:creator: TONY IYARE and MATT STEVENS

item.title: Polish Catholics Gather at Border for Vast Rosary Prayer Event
item.media:description: People walked through a forest near Poland’s border with the Czech Republic during a rosary prayer on Saturday. Some participants said they were demonstrating against the spread of Islam’s influence.
item.description: Organizers called the rosary “a mighty weapon against evil” and expected it would draw a million people. Some participants said they were demonstrating against the spread of Islam.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Mexican Radio Host’s Resignation Highlights Ties Between Government and Media
item.media:description: The radio host Leonardo Curzio during a lecture at the Universidad del Valle de México in February. Mr. Curzio quit in protest over demands to fire his colleagues.
item.description: Leonardo Curzio quit in protest over demands to fire two co-hosts, and he compared the government’s influence over the media to “a disease that kills you slowly.”
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Hosting Proms and Selling Cows: North Korean Embassies Scrounge for Cash
item.media:description: A Chinese paramilitary officer standing guard outside the North Korean embassy in Beijing.
item.description: Desperate for hard currency to keep their operations afloat, diplomats from the so-called hermit kingdom smuggle liquor, drugs, cars and guns — and engage in more mundane activities.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL

item.title: Russians, Heeding Navalny’s Call, Mark Putin’s Birthday With Protest
item.media:description: A crowd of mostly young people joined an antigovernment demonstration called by the jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny in Moscow on Saturday.
item.description: Youths across Russia answered a protest call from the jailed opposition leader, Aleksei Navalny, but bad weather and fear of a harsh police response limited the turnout in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Car Crashes Into Pedestrians in London
item.description: The London police detained a driver on Saturday after his car injured several pedestrians near the Natural History Museum. The crash, police said, appeared to be a “road traffic collision” and not terrorism.

item.title: Amid Catalan Crisis, Thousands Hold Rallies in Madrid and Barcelona
item.media:description: Demonstrators, mostly dressed in white, gathered in Sant Jaume square in Barcelona, Spain, on Saturday to call for Catalan and Spanish leaders to work together.
item.description: People thronged to demonstrations in the two cities as Catalan leaders appeared on the verge of announcing independence.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY and JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Tropical Storm Nate Kills 22 in Central America Amid Flooding and Landslides
item.media:description: People traveling by bus were trapped by landslides caused by Tropical Storm Nate near Casa Mata, Costa Rica.
item.description: At least 22 people were killed across Costa Rica, Honduras and Nicaragua. The storm was upgraded to a hurricane as it plowed toward the Gulf Coast.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: In Long-Isolated Sudan, ‘Lot of Excitement’ as U.S. Sanctions End
item.media:description: A fruit stand in Omdurman. A host of American sanctions will be lifted permanently this coming week.
item.description: Economic sanctions imposed on Sudan had turned it into a pariah state, with a national airline reduced to one plane. Their lifting is expected to increase Western investment.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
